facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 426 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.426 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 21, 1955, of the Orissa High Court at Cuttack in Special Jurisdiction Case No. 179 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 21, 1955, of the Orissa High Court at Cuttack in Special Jurisdiction Case No. 179 of 1951.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 14, 1958 by Venkatarama Aiyar, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.-

facts.text: Appeal against Orissa High Court judgment in reference under s.66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Orrissa in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act,

facts.text: Issue: whether income from sale of trees growing in respondent's forests is agricultural income exempt under s.4(3)(viii).

anchor.surface_text: and the point for decision is whether income received by the respondent by the sale of trees growing in his forests is agricultural income exempt from taxation under s. 4(3)(viii) of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent is proprietor of impartible zamin of Jaipur in Koraput District.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the proprietor of the impartable zamin of Jaipur in Koraput District.

facts.text: Estate area is 12,000 sq. miles, of which 1540 sq. miles reserve forest and 100 sq. miles protected forest.

anchor.surface_text: The estate is of the area of 12,000 sq. miles of which 1540 sq. miles are reserve forest and 100 sq. miles, protected forest.

facts.text: Respondent derives income from forests by sale of timber such as teak, salwood, lac, myrabolam, tamarind, cashewnuts and firewood.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent derives income from the forests by the sale of timber such as teak, salwood, lac, myrabolam, tamarind, cashewnuts and firewood.

facts.text: No dispute as to receipt of income or its quantum; appears in respondent's account books.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute either as to the receipt of such income or as to its quantum. All that appears in the account books of the respondent.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer by order dated January 31, 1943 held forests not proved planted by respondent, trees spontaneous growth, income not exempt under s.4(3)(viii).

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated January 31, 1943, the Income-tax Officer held that the forests in question had not been proved to have been planted by the respondent,

facts.text: Order of ITO confirmed on appeal by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: and that the income therefrom was not within the exemption under s. 4(3)(viii) and this order was confirmed on appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Appellate Tribunal, contending ITO failed to consider Dewan letter dated June 3, 1942 detailing forest operations.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took the matter in further appeal to the Appellate Tribunal, and there put forward the contention that the Income-tax Officer had failed to take into account a letter of the Dewan dated June 3, 1942,

facts.text: Tribunal by order dated April 9, 1946 accepted contention, directed fresh enquiry into facts in Dewan letter.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated April 9, 1946, the Tribunal accepted this contention, and directed a fresh enquiry into the facts mentioned in the said letter.

facts.text: On fresh enquiry, ITO found no materials proving plantation, no plantation books or working plans produced, held forests natural growth, income assessable.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order, the Income-tax Officer again enquired into the matter. He observed that though he gave ample opportunities to the respondent to prove that there was plantation of trees by the estate, no materials were placed in proof of that fact

facts.text: Tribunal found no substantial evidence of cultivation/plantation by zamin, no expenses prior to 1904 or negligible, trees sold not those planted.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this contention, the Tribunal observed that though there had been extensive destruction of forests in the process of Podu cultivation, nevertheless, considerable areas of virgin forests still survived, that the evidence of actual cultivation and plantation by the zamin authorities was meagre and unsubstantial,

facts.text: Tribunal order covered assessments for five years 1942-43 to 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned that this order covered the assessments for five years from 1942-43 to 1946-47, the facts relating to the character of the income being the same for all the years.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: Whether income derived from forest taxable under Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the respondent, the Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court Whether on the facts and in the circumstances the income derived from forest in this case is taxable under the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Orissa HC (Panigrahi CJ, Misra J) answered reference in negative (not taxable).

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Panigrahi, C. J., and Misra, J., who answered it in the negative.

facts.text: HC held department failed to prove income not agricultural; onus on department.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, they held that the Department had failed to establish that the income derived from the sale of trees was not agricultural income, and answered the reference in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds onus on claimant of exemption (respondent) to prove agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, we should dissent from the view expressed by the learned Judges that the burden is on the Department to prove that the income sought to be taxed is not agricultural income.

facts.text: Tribunal found no plantations by estate authorities, trees of spontaneous growth.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Tribunal has clearly found that there were no plantations of trees by the estate authorities worth the name, and that the trees, the income from which is the subject matter of the assessments, must have been of spontaneous growth.

facts.text: Tribunal finding of fact binding in reference under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: That is a finding of fact which is binding on the Court in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Act.

facts.text: Podu cultivation: felling jungle, burning, sowing dry grain without tilling for two years, then abandon.

anchor.surface_text: What this Podu cultivation means is thus stated in the District Gazetteer, Vishakapatnam, 1907 This consists in felling a piece of jungle, burning the felled trees and undergrowth, sowing dry grain broadcast in the ashes without any kind of tilling for two years in succession,

The following are the figures relating to the forest receipts and expenses for the years with which the present assessments are concerned Years Receipts Expenses 1942-43 Rs. 438,894 Rs. 174,437 1943-44 Rs. 407,447 Rs. 209,895

facts.text: Appeal allowed, HC order set aside, reference answered in affirmative (taxable).

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

holdings.text: The burden of proof is on the assessee claiming exemption from tax as agricultural income under s.4(3)(viii); not on the Department to disprove it.

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, we should dissent from the view expressed by the learned Judges that the burden is on the Department to prove that the income sought to be taxed is not agricultural income. The law is well settled that it is for a person who claims exemption to establish it, and there is no reason why it should be otherwise when the exemption claimed is under the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissents from High Court; cites English cases (Maughan, Keren Kayemeth), Indian cases (Amritsar Produce, Charusila Dassi), and recent SC decision in Venkataswamy Naidu holding assessee must prove exemption.

holdings.text: Finding of fact by Tribunal that there were no plantations of trees by estate authorities worth the name and trees were of spontaneous growth is binding on court in reference under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Tribunal has clearly found that there were no plantations of trees by the estate authorities worth the name, and that the trees, the income from which is the subject matter of the assessments, must have been of spontaneous growth. That is a finding of fact which is binding on the Court in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal finding on facts not reviewable in s.66(1) reference; High Court erred in reappreciating evidence.

holdings.text: Agricultural income under s.2(1) requires derivation from land by agriculture involving basic operations like tilling, sowing, planting; subsequent operations (preservation, pruning) insufficient alone.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, the question what is agricultural income within s. 2(1) of the Act is the subject of a recent decision of this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy. There, it was held that before an income could be held to be agricultural income, it must be shown to have been derived from land by agriculture or by one or the other of the operations described in cls. (i) and (ii) of s. 2(1)(b) of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows and applies recent SC decision in Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy defining agriculture; distinguishes spontaneous growth products not involving basic operations.

holdings.text: Income from sale of trees of spontaneous growth is not agricultural income notwithstanding preservation efforts or organized forest maintenance.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with trees which grow wild, Bhagwati, J., observed It is agreed on all hands that products which grow wild on the land or are of spontaneous growth not involving any human labour or skill upon the land are not products of agriculture and the income derived therefrom is not agricultural income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Benoy Kumar: no basic operations for spontaneous trees; preservation is subsequent operation only.

holdings.text: Income received by respondent from sale of trees growing in forests is not agricultural income exempt under s.4(3)(viii); taxable under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the law being thus settled, in order to decide whether the income received by the respondent by the sale of trees in his forests was agricultural income or not, the crucial question to be answered is, were those trees planted by the proprietors of the estate, or did they grow spontaneously? ... In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines binding Tribunal fact (spontaneous growth, no plantation), burden on assessee (not discharged), and ag income definition (no basic ops); rejects Podu, accounts arguments.

holdings.text: Podu cultivation evidence irrelevant to whether estate authorities planted trees; regrowth from stumps after Podu is spontaneous, not plantation.

anchor.surface_text: the law being thus settled, in order to decide whether the income received by the respondent by the sale of trees in his forests was agricultural income or not, the crucial question to be answered is, were those trees planted by the proprietors of the estate, or did they grow spontaneously? If it is the latter, it would be wholly immaterial that the respondent has maintained a large establishment for the purpose of preserving the forests and assisting in the growth of the trees, because ex hypothes, he performed no basic operations for bringing the forests into being.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point for decision is plantation by estate, not age/virgin status; no evidence of estate planting post-Podu; HC finding of stump regrowth confirms spontaneous.

holdings.text: High forest maintenance expenses do not prove substantial income from planted trees where Tribunal finds no plantations.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to deal with one other contention urged on behalf of the respondent, and that is based on the fact that the amounts spent in the upkeep of the forests were large in comparison with the receipts therefrom. ... In the face of the clear finding in the present case that the forests with which the assessment years are concerned were of spontaneous growth, the observations quoted above can be of no assistance to the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Benoy Kumar context (admitted plantations); here binding no-plantation finding overrides expense inference.

precedents.citation: Australian Mutual Provident Society Inland Revenue Commissioners 1946 1 All E.R. 528

anchor.surface_text: Australian Mutual Provident Society Inland Revenue Commissioners 1 The rule must be construed together with the exempting provisions which, in our opinion, must be regarded as paramount.

precedents.case_name: Australian Mutual Provident Society v Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: exempting provisions are paramount and rules must be construed so as not to indirectly deprive of exemption benefit
precedents.cited_holding: The rule must be construed together with the exempting provisions which, in our opinion, must be regarded as paramount. So far as the rule, if taken in isolation, would have the effect of indirectly depriving the company of any part of the benefit of the exemption, its operation must be cut down

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v Venkataswamy Naidu
precedents.cited_proposition: it was for the assessee to prove that the income sought to be taxed was agricultural income exempt under s. 4(3)(viii)
precedents.cited_holding: the assessee had to put before the Income-tax Authorities proper materials ... It was not for the Income-tax Authorities to prove that it was not agricultural income

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy 1958 S.C.R. 101

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy 1 . There, it was held that before an income could be held to be agricultural income,

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: agricultural income must be derived from land by agriculture involving basic operations like tilling, sowing of seeds, planting; spontaneous growth products are not agricultural income; subsequent operations alone do not qualify
precedents.cited_holding: the term agriculture meant ... basic operations as tilling of the land, sowing of seeds, planting ... products which grow wild ... or are of spontaneous growth not involving any human labour or skill ... are not products of agriculture

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy 1958 S.C.R. 101

anchor.surface_text: This view is numberlonger tenable in view of the decision of this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy 1 . It is contended by Mr. Viswanatha Sastri

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: subsequent operations alone without basic operations do not make income agricultural

anchor.surface_text: And support for this conclusion is sought in the following observations in The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy 1 The expenditure shown by the assessee for the maintenance of the forest

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, we should dissent from the view expressed by the learned Judges that the burden is on the Department to prove that the income sought to be taxed is not agricultural income. The law is well settled that it is for a person who claims exemption to establish it, and there is no reason why it should be otherwise when the exemption claimed is under the Income-tax Act.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Tribunal has clearly found that there were no plantations of trees by the estate authorities worth the name, and that the trees, the income from which is the subject matter of the assessments, must have been of spontaneous growth. That is a finding of fact which is binding on the Court in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Act.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

On the merits, the question what is agricultural income within s. 2(1) of the Act is the subject of a recent decision of this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy. There, it was held that before an income could be held to be agricultural income, it must be shown to have been derived from land by agriculture or by one or the other of the operations described in cls. (i) and (ii) of s. 2(1)(b) of the Act,
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with trees which grow wild, Bhagwati, J., observed It is agreed on all hands that products which grow wild on the land or are of spontaneous growth not involving any human labour or skill upon the land are not products of agriculture and the income derived therefrom is not agricultural income.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: the law being thus settled, in order to decide whether the income received by the respondent by the sale of trees in his forests was agricultural income or not, the crucial question to be answered is, were those trees planted by the proprietors of the estate, or did they grow spontaneously? ... In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

the law being thus settled, in order to decide whether the income received by the respondent by the sale of trees in his forests was agricultural income or not, the crucial question to be answered is, were those trees planted by the proprietors of the estate, or did they grow spontaneously? If it is the latter, it would be wholly immaterial that the respondent has maintained a large establishment for the purpose of preserving the forests and assisting in the growth of the trees, because ex hypothes, he performed no basic operations for bringing the forests into being.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.

It remains to deal with one other contention urged on behalf of the respondent, and that is based on the fact that the amounts spent in the upkeep of the forests were large in comparison with the receipts therefrom. ... In the face of the clear finding in the present case that the forests with which the assessment years are concerned were of spontaneous growth, the observations quoted above can be of no assistance to the respondent.
In the result, this appeal is allowed, the order of the Court below is set aside and the reference is answered in the affirmative.
